context: In April 1994, the results of a Merck-sponsored study, the <a3_0><b13_0>Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study<b13_0/><a3_0/>, were announced. Researchers tested simvastatin, later sold by Merck as <a5_0>Zocor<a5_0/>, on <a2_0><b12_0>4,444<b12_0/><a2_0/> patients with high cholesterol and heart disease. After five years, the study concluded the patients saw <a4_0><b14_0>a <a6_0>35%<a6_0/> reduction in their cholesterol, and their chances of dying of a heart attack were reduced by <a7_0>42%<b14_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/>. In 1995, Zocor and Mevacor both made Merck <a1_0><a8_0><b11_0>over US$1 billion<b11_0/><a8_0/><a1_0/>. <a0_0><b10_0>Endo<b10_0/><a0_0/> was awarded the 2006 Japan Prize, and the <a9_0>Lasker-DeBakey Clinical Medical Research Award<a9_0/> in 2008.
